clinical_study.brief_title: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBTi) in Patients With Mental Illness
clinical_study.official_title: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBTi) in Patients With Mental Illness

brief_summary.textblock: Insomnia is common in patients with co-morbid mental illness and sleeping difficulties is a frequent complaint in most psychological disorders. Mental illness may cause sleep problems, however, sleep problems like insomnia, may also cause or exacerbate mental illness. Insomnia may aggravate symptoms of depression, anxiety and fatigue, and reduce daily functioning in patients with co-morbid insomnia and mental illness. This project aims to evaluate a course offered to patients with insomnia and mental illness at Diakonhjemmet Hospital. The course is based on cognitive behavioral therapy, a documented treatment for insomnia.

primary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline (before first session), at session 6 (last ordinary session, 5-7 weeks after baseline), at session 7 (2 months after last ordinary session) and 6 months after completing the course.
primary_outcome.description: All patients included in the study will be asked to complete the Insomnia Severity Index (ISI; Minimum value = 0; Maximum value = 4. Higher scores mean worse outcome) to assess for any changes in symptoms of insomnia.

primary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline (before first session), at session 6 (last ordinary session, 5-7 weeks after baseline), at session 7 (2 months after last ordinary session) and 6 months after completing the course.
primary_outcome.description: All patients included in the study will be asked to complete the Bergen Insomnia Scale ( Minimum value = 0; Maximum value = 7. Higher scores mean worse outcome) to assess for any changes in symptoms of insomnia.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Calculations of sleep efficiency at baseline (before first session), at session 6 (last ordinary session, 5-7 weeks after baseline), at session 7 (2 months after last ordinary session) and 6 months after completing the course, will be compared.
secondary_outcome.description: All patients included in the study will be asked to keep a sleep diary for the whole duration of the course. Sleep efficiency will be calculated based on the sleep diary.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in dysfunctional beliefs and attitudes about sleep
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline (before first session), at session 6 (last ordinary session, 5-7 weeks after baseline), at session 7 (2 months after last ordinary session) and 6 months after completing the course.
secondary_outcome.description: All patients included in the study will be asked to complete the Dysfunctional Beliefs and Attitudes about Sleep scale (DBAS-16; Minimum = 0; Maximum = 10. Higher values mean worse outcome) to assess for any changes in dysfunctional beliefs and attitudes about sleep.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in daytime rumination about tiredness and negative consequences of lack of sleep
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline (before first session), at session 6 (last ordinary session, 5-7 weeks after baseline), at session 7 (2 months after last ordinary session) and 6 months after completing the course.
secondary_outcome.description: All patients included in the study will be asked to complete the Daytime Insomnia Symptom Response Scale (DISRS; Minimum = 1; Maximum = 4. Higher values mean worse outcome) to assess for any changes in rumination about insomnia symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in compliance with sleep hygiene measures
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline (before first session), at session 6 (last ordinary session, 5-7 weeks after baseline), at session 7 (2 months after last ordinary session) and 6 months after completing the course.
secondary_outcome.description: All patients included in the study will be asked to complete the Sleep Hygiene Index (SHI-13; Minimum value = 1; Maximum value = 5. Higher values mean worse outcome) to assess for any changes in compliance with sleep hygiene measures.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline (before first session), at session 6 (last ordinary session, 5-7 weeks after baseline), at session 7 (2 months after last ordinary session) and 6 months after completing the course.
secondary_outcome.description: All patients included in the study will be asked to complete the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9; Minimum value = 0; Maximum value = 3. Higher values mean worse outcome) to assess for any changes in symptoms of depression.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline (before first session), at session 6 (last ordinary session, 5-7 weeks after baseline), at session 7 (2 months after last ordinary session) and 6 months after completing the course.
secondary_outcome.description: All patients included in the study will be asked to complete the Generalized Anxiety Disorder Scale-7 (GAD-7; Minimum value = 0; Maximum value = 3. Higher values mean worse outcome) to assess for any changes in symptoms of anxiety.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline (before first session), at session 6 (last ordinary session, 5-7 weeks after baseline), at session 7 (2 months after last ordinary session) and 6 months after completing the course.
secondary_outcome.description: All patients included in the study will be asked to complete the Somatic Symptom Scale-9 (SSS-8; Minimum value = 0; Maximum value = 4. Higher value mean worse outcome) to assess for any changes in somatic symptom burden.

intervention.description: Patients will undergo a 7 sessions course in cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Men and women over 18 years with insomnia and co-morbid mental illness.
- Is a patient and receiving treatment for mental illness at Department of Psychiatry, Diakonhjemmet Hospital, at time of referral to the course
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to provide informed consent
- Unable to read and/or understand Norwegian
- Unable to complete a survey
- Severe mental disorder, e.g. schizophrenia and bipolar disorder type I
- Mental retardation or dementia
- Known substance abuse
- Other sleep disorder, e.g. narcolepsy and hypersomnia
